channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: How Western Goods Reach Russia: A Long Line of Trucks Through Georgia
item.description: With Western sanctions barring many imports, a lot of what Russia needs now travels a slow, crowded truck route through the Caucasus Mountains from Georgia.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The long, winding lines of cargo trucks waiting to cross from Georgia into Russia more than doubled last year, the Russian government says.

item.title: Afghan Women Are Devastated by Suspension of Aid Under New Taliban Law
item.description: Since the Taliban administration banned women from aid work, many groups have suspended their operations in the country and warned of permanently shutting down if the ban remains.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 15-month-old, Fatima, and her mother at the overwhelmed malnutrition ward of Indira Gandhi Hospital, the largest pediatric hospital in Kabul, last year. Many aid organizations have warned that the malnutrition crisis will drastically worsen if the ban on women in aid work remains.

item.title: She Witnessed Mao’s Worst Excesses. Now She Has a Warning for the World.
item.description: At 93, the memoirist Yuan-tsung Chen hopes that her recollections of China’s tumultuous past will help the country confront its historical wrongs — and avoid repeating them.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The author Yuan-tsung Chen at her home in Hong Kong in July. Her latest book is “The Secret Listener: An Ingenue in Mao’s Court.”

item.title: Russia Says It Has Taken Besieged Town as Kyiv Denies the Claim
item.description: There have been conflicting reports for days about who controls the small eastern town of Soledar, which has taken on outsize attention as Moscow seeks a victory.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a funeral for a Ukrainian soldier in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: With FBI Search, US Escalates Global Fight Over Chinese Police Outposts
item.description: Beijing says the outposts aren’t doing police work, but Chinese state media reports say they “collect intelligence” and solve crimes far outside their jurisdiction.
item.dc:creator: Megha Rajagopalan and William K. Rashbaum
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: F.B.I. agents searched a suspected Chinese police outpost located at this glass building on East Broadway in New York’s Chinatown.

item.title: Investigation Blames Negligence, Poor Planning for Seoul Crowd Crush
item.description: Investigators want 23 people indicted but cleared senior authorities of fault in the Halloween tragedy. Victims’ families disputed the inquiry’s findings.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A police officer guarding the site of the crowd crush in Seoul in October.

item.title: U.A.E. Names Oil Executive to Lead Climate Talks at COP28
item.description: Sultan Al Jaber, who heads the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, was chosen by the United Arab Emirates to head the upcoming COP28 summit, drawing criticism from green groups.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Vivian Nereim
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Sultan Al Jaber has for over a decade been at the front of the U.A.E.’s efforts to build a more sustainable future even as it continues to produce oil.

item.title: Greek Court Drops Espionage Charges Against Aid Workers
item.description: The 24 defendants had been charged with misdemeanors over their work with migrants, but they still face more serious charges.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters, lawyers and aid workers outside a court in Mytilene, on the Greek island of Lesbos, on Friday.

item.title: Kevin Spacey Pleads Not Guilty to 7 Charges of Sexual Misconduct in U.K.
item.description: The Oscar-winning actor had already pleaded not guilty in July to five other counts of sexual misconduct. He is currently out on bail.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Kevin Spacey outside the Old Bailey in London last July.

item.title: Western Tanks Appear Headed to Ukraine, Breaking Another Taboo
item.description: The West has sent an array of weapons once seen as too provocative, and it looks like tanks will be next. With a new Russian offensive expected, officials see an urgent need to shift the balance.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: A Ukrainian tank in the Lyman district, Donetsk region, last month.

item.title: Iran Protests: People Executed or Sentenced to Death in Crackdown
item.description: An updated look at the Iranians who have been hanged, and those on death row, as the government tries to crush a monthslong uprising.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Via Getty Images; via Amnesty; via Twitter; via Radio Zamaneh
item.media:description: In a one-month period, four men were executed after fast-tracked trials in Iran. They are, from left: Majid Reza Rahnavard, Mohammad Mehdi Karami, Mohsen Shekari and Sayed Mohammad Hosseini.

item.title: In a First, South Korea Declares Nuclear Weapons a Policy Option
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol said that if North Korea’s nuclear threat grows, his country may build a nuclear arsenal of its own or ask the United States to redeploy in the South.​
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea in Seoul on Tuesday.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul Proposal Sets Off Fury in Israel
item.description: A proposal to weaken the Supreme Court has set off an early backlash against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s new hard-right government.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Lawyers protested the Israeli government’s plans to overhaul the judicial system, outside the Tel Aviv District Court of Justice on Thursday.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Former President Ordered to Pay Compensation Over 2019 Bombings
item.description: A Supreme Court ruling denounced former President Maithripala Sirisena and some of his top officials for what it called “reckless failure” to prevent the attacks, which killed more than 200 people.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives lighting candles after the burial of three victims of the same family who died in the bombing at St. Sebastian Church in Negombo, Sri Lanka, in 2019.

item.title: Iran Executes Alireza Akbari, Ex-Official Accused of Spying
item.description: Alireza Akbari, previously a senior military and defense official, had moved to Britain a decade ago. He had been detained since 2019.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Khabar Online, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Alireza Akbari in an undated photo. A former defense minister in Iran and a dual citizen of Iran and Britain, he had been detained in Iran since 2019.

item.title: Bolsonaro Faces Investigation for Inspiring Brazil’s Capital Riot
item.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court said it would investigate Jair Bolsonaro, the country’s former president, for inspiring the mob that stormed the nation’s halls of power on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, Brazil’s former president, speaking to supporters at a rally in October ahead of an election later that month that he lost.

item.title: Biden Administration Faces Resistance to Plan to Sell F-16s to Turkey
item.description: The State Department has contacted Congress about major arms deals for Turkey and Greece, but a prominent senator is strongly opposed to the Ankara sale.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: The $20 billion arms package for Turkey would include 40 new F-16 fighter jets.

item.title: No Increased Stroke Risk Linked to Pfizer’s Covid Boosters, Federal Officials Say
item.description: An uptick hinted at in surveillance data was a mirage, the officials said.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: A booster vaccination clinic in Salt Lake City last year.

item.title: How a Mob Tried to Oust Brazil’s Lula
item.description: The storming of Brazil’s capital failed to overthrow the elected government. But an examination of the attack reveals how extremism is threatening Latin America’s largest democracy.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Simon Romero

item.title: Peter Grose, Veteran Foreign Correspondent, Dies at 88
item.description: His career with The New York Times took him to Saigon and Moscow. He drew on that experience later to write several well-received books.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Gentleman Spy: The Life of Allen Dulles (Book)
item.media:description: The foreign correspondent Peter Grose, seated at left, in The New York Times’s Saigon bureau in 1965. With him were the bureau assistant Nguyen Ngoc Rao, standing, and Mr. Grose’s fellow Times journalists Seymour Topping, center, and A.J. Langguth.

item.title: Russia’s Claim to Seize Soledar in Ukraine Exposes Rifts Among Forces
item.description: After Russia’s Defense Ministry said its troops had taken Soledar, a leader of the Wagner mercenary group accused the military of stealing credit. Ukraine said its forces were still fighting there.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas, Megan Specia and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A frame from a video released by the Russian Defense Ministry on Friday purportedly showed self-propelled howitzers firing in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Sweden Says It Has Uncovered a Rare Earth Bonanza
item.description: A state-owned mining company announced it had found Europe’s largest deposit of the vital minerals used in electric vehicles and other green technology.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:description: LKAB’s iron ore mine in Kiruna, Sweden. The company said it had found Europe’s largest deposit of rare earth minerals.

item.title: Constantine II, the Last King of Greece, Dies at 82
item.description: An Olympic medalist, he was popular when he took the throne in 1964. But his efforts to intervene in Greek politics led to a coup and his ouster.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Prince Constantine, center, an avid sportsman, won a gold medal in sailing in the 1960 Olympics.

item.title: Biden and Kishida Vow to Bolster US-Japan Alliance as China’s Power Grows
item.description: The two leaders discussed tensions with China, North Korea and Russia and plans for deterrence in Asia with U.S. troops and missiles.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden met with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan at the White House on Friday. Mr. Kishida had met with European, British and Canadian leaders in their countries before his visit to Washington.

item.title: How the Biden Administration is Battling the Border Surge
item.description: The Biden administration’s border policy relies on Mexico for crucial help.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants wait in line at the border in El Paso, Texas, as seen from Ciudad Juárez, Mexico in December.

item.title: The Great New Zealand Egg Shortage
item.description: Prices are up, and some parts of the country have seen bare shelves where eggs normally are. One reason is a change in how chickens are being raised.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Chickens in Kaukapakapa, New Zealand. Don’t tell them that the average New Zealander consumes about 237 eggs each year.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Investigating Chinese Police Outposts Abroad
item.description: Also, Xi Jinping changes his tone on business and South Korea considers nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL E. SLOTNIK
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: F.B.I. agents searched a suspected Chinese police outpost located at this glass building on East Broadway in New York’s Chinatown.

item.title: Girl Guides of Canada Drops Brownies Name
item.description: The organization adopted a new name, Embers, for the branch after current and former members said that the old one was a barrier to belonging.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Exxon Scientists Predicted Global Warming, Even as Company Cast Doubts, Study Finds
item.description: Starting in the 1970s, scientists working for the oil giant made remarkably accurate projections of just how much burning fossil fuels would warm the planet.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: The Esso Atlantic in 1981. The ship conducted scientific research for Exxon.

item.title: Who Is Valery Gerasimov, the New Head of Russia’s War Effort in Ukraine?
item.description: In a statement announcing the appointment, the Russian Defense Ministry hinted at a renewed campaign in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Mikhail Klimentyev/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Valery Gerasimov, seated right, Russia’s highest-ranking military officer, overseeing military exercises in September, alongside President Vladimir V. Putin, second left.

item.title: Russia Released US Navy Veteran Quietly Detained for 9 Months
item.description: The veteran, Taylor Dudley, had traveled to Poland to attend a music festival and “at some point crossed the Russian border,” a family spokesman said. It remained unclear on what charges he had been held.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: The U.S. Embassy in Moscow in June.

item.title: Driver in Guangzhou, China, Runs Down Pedestrians, Killing at Least 5
item.description: The police in Guangzhou detained a 22-year-old man, who appeared to throw money in the air after striking the people. Thirteen people were injured.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: An image from a video taken Wednesday at an intersection in Guangzhou, China, after numerous pedestrians were struck by an S.U.V.

item.title: Poland and Britain Consider Sending Leopard Tanks to Ukraine
item.description: U.S. and European defense officials have long held concerns that giving Ukraine tanks could prompt Russia to escalate the war.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Leopard II tanks during a military exercise in Zagan, Poland, in 2019.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Aides have found more files retained by President Biden dating from his vice presidency.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden has said his staff had fully cooperated with the National Archives.

item.title: Video Shows Brazil Rioters Breaching Inadequate Security
item.description: The invasion of Brazil’s halls of power began with a severe shortfall of security forces.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, André Spigariol, Flávia Milhorance and Ana Ionova

item.title: U.S. and Japan Say They Will Strengthen Military Cooperation
item.description: Top officials from the two nations are meeting in Washington this week to discuss tensions with China, Russia and North Korea and to plan for deterrence with U.S. troops and missiles.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Airborne troops from the United States, Japan, Britain and Australia participated in joint exercises in Funabashi, Japan, on Monday.

item.title: Russia Replaces Commander for Ukraine War, as Signs of Dissension Grow
item.description: Allies of President Vladimir V. Putin contradicted each other about battlefield progress, as a war command shake-up put another Kremlin loyalist in charge.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Ukrainians firing a mortar toward Russian positions near Bakhmut on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran Gives Death Sentence to Former Defense Official, a Dual U.K. Citizen
item.description: Alireza Akbari, a former deputy defense minister, was convicted of spying, in a case he described as a slap at Britain, where he had lived.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Alireza Akbari

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Russian Military Shake-Up
item.description: Also, Brazil investigates the riots and Australia reacts to Cardinal George Pell’s death.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers turn away as a 152mm Howitzer is fired into the Russian controlled town of Pisky, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Navalny’s Wife Pleads for Medical Treatment for Jailed Husband
item.description: Yulia Navalny said that her ailing husband, Aleksei Navalny, was being held in a small cell with a sicker person to infect him, and was not allowed to lie down throughout the day despite having a fever.
item.dc:creator: Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, in a video link from prison in September last year.

item.title: A Vital Question for Brazil’s Democracy: Where Were the Police?
item.description: Their early inaction in Sunday’s riot shows how security forces can help empower violence and deepen the threat to democracy.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brazilian military police officers in Brasília, the capital, during the attack on Sunday.

item.title: Rehman Rahi, 97, Eminent Kashmiri Poet Who Restored a Language, Dies
item.description: Kashmir’s unofficial poet laureate, he gave voice to the rich culture of a bitterly divided territory and helped give his mother tongue a distinct literary identity.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Sipra Das/The The India Today Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Rehman Rahi in 2007, after becoming the first Kashmiri to win India’s highest literary award.

item.title: Kyiv Workers Find Their Way Online Even as Ukraine Faces Power Outages
item.description: Sporadic power outages have people resorting to makeshift office spaces in the Ukrainian capital. Stores have set up power hubs, and workers are getting comfortable doing their jobs in home furnishing displays.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uliana Kychenko, a freelance marketing manager, works from a table in a co-working space set up in Epicentr, a department store in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.

item.title: In Israel, Netanyahu’s Hard-Right Agenda Gains Steam
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu’s government is pushing to upend the judiciary, entrench Israeli control of the West Bank and strengthen ultraconservative Jews, fueling protests and deepening Israel’s divisions.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: An election rally for Benjamin Netanyahu in Sderot, Israel, in October. Mr. Netanyahu said this week that voters had given his government “a clear and strong mandate.”

item.title: Ukraine Strips a Pro-Putin Politician of His Citizenship
item.description: Viktor Medvedchuk, a Ukrainian politician who is close to the Russian president, was handed over to Moscow in September as part of a prisoner swap while awaiting trial on treason charges.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Viktor Medvedchuk, center, leaving a court hearing in Kyiv, Ukraine, in 2021.

item.title: Another Big Boomer Effect
item.description: One generation’s impact on the work force.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:description: Construction employers have continued to add jobs at a solid pace.

item.title: Zelensky Thanks the ‘Free World’ in a Message at the Golden Globes
item.description: “There will be no third world war,” the Ukrainian president said. “It is not a trilogy. Ukraine will stop the Russian aggression on our land.”
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs

item.title: They Won Guantánamo’s Supreme Court Cases. Where Are They Now?
item.description: The three former Guantánamo prisoners who defeated George W. Bush at the Supreme Court in landmark cases are ensconced in family life. We caught up with two of them. One is a home-heating serviceman in central England; the other is an Uber driver in the French Riviera.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg and Cristina Baussan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Cristina Baussan for The New York Times

item.title: ‘A Wild Card’: Son of Uganda’s President Jostles to Succeed His Father
item.description: Gen. Muhoozi Kainerugaba has been positioning himself as Uganda’s next leader. But his provocative tweets have unnerved Ugandans and put his father in a bind.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Gen. Muhoozi Kainerugaba at his birthday party in Entebbe, Uganda, in May.

item.title: Online Anger Over China’s Covid Pivot Shows Widening Social Split
item.description: The Communist Party’s efforts to limit discord over its sudden “zero Covid” pivot are being challenged with increasing rancor, including from its own supporters.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che, Claire Fu and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Passengers pushing their luggage through the international arrivals hall at Beijing Capital International Airport in January after China lifted its quarantine requirement for inbound travelers.

item.title: The New Soldiers in Propane’s Fight Against Climate Action: Television Stars
item.description: An industry group is spending millions of dollars to push back against efforts to move heating away from oil and gas.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi

item.title: Uganda’s Worst Ebola Outbreak in Two Decades Is Over, W.H.O. Declares
item.description: The virus spread to nine districts nationwide, infecting hundreds and killing dozens. Seven health workers were among those who died.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A victim of Ebola being buried in Mubende, Uganda, in October. The country has endured several Ebola outbreaks over the years.

item.title: Paris Police ‘Neutralize’ Man After Stabbings at Gare du Nord
item.description: An assailant injured six people with what French authorities described as a sharpened metal hook. The motive was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: French police officers secured the area after an attack at the Gare du Nord train station in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: At least 17 more civilians have died in extraordinary violence in Peru.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Juan Carlos Cisneros/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hundreds of protesters gathering on Monday in the Andean region of Puno in support of the ousted president, Pedro Castillo.

item.title: Biden Defends His Immigration Policy as Summit in Mexico Wraps Up
item.description: Even as President Biden and the leaders of Canada and Mexico sought to emphasize their shared commitments, the tricky issue of immigration dominated much of the discussion.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Anushka Patil
item.media:description: President Biden, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada in Mexico City on Tuesday.

item.title: George Pell, Cardinal Whose Abuse Conviction Was Overturned, Dies at 81
item.description: An adviser to Pope Francis and a prominent figure in Australia, Cardinal Pell went to prison on charges of abusing two boys in the 1990s, but a higher court later acquitted him.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Damien Cave
item.media:description: Cardinal George Pell in Sydney in 2008. He later became one of the highest-ranking figures at the Vatican.

item.title: Wagner Group Claims It Has Taken Soledar, an Eastern Ukrainian Town
item.description: With a harsh winter putting sweeping offensives on hold, the war has shifted back to bloody battles of attrition like the one for the small city of Bakhmut and the smaller town of Soledar.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Ivan Nechepurenko and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing a 152-mm howitzer into the Russian-held town of Pisky, in the Donetsk region, on Monday.

item.title: After Rocky Start, Biden Builds Rapport with Mexico President López Obrador
item.description: Warm gestures by the American president have helped cement a critical relationship with a Mexican leader whose cooperation on migration, climate change and the drug trade is crucial.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden with President Andrés Manuel López Obrador at the National Palace in Mexico City on Monday.

item.title: Brazilian Authorities Arrested the Rioters. Now They Are Arresting Security Officials.
item.description: With more than 700 people arrested after supporters of Jair Bolsonaro ransacked Brazil’s seats of government, the authorities began to search for those who funded and aided the rioters.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova, André Spigariol and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some supporters of Brazil’s former President Jair Bolsonaro who were arrested after Sunday’s attack in Brasília were released on Tuesday.

item.title: Prince Harry Skewers Palace Culture With Nicknames and a Dose of Rancor
item.description: Along with the juicy tidbits Prince Harry offers up in his new memoir, there is also a revealing look at how the royal family, and its staff, operate behind closed doors.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display of Prince Harry’s book in the window at Waterstones in Piccadilly, central London.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Shanghai’s Devastating Outbreak
item.description: Also, the eight warmest years on record and a fragile political alliance in the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patients and their loved ones in the lobby of a Shanghai hospital on Friday.
